citeinfo.title: Plankton Bloom - Alaska Sea Grant Radio Show

descript.abstract: In 1997, at the height of an El Ni￱o summer, a massive plankton bloom turned the sea off Alaska the color of milk, and killed hundreds of thousands of seabirds. Now, scientists say that bloom may have triggered profound changes in the ocean food web. Doug Schneider has more, in this week's Arctic Science Journeys Radio.
descript.purpose: Looking out from the wheelhouse of the research vessel Alpha Helix, things on Alaska's Bering Sea appear normal. Dall's porpoises dart across the front of the ship, while gray whales breach in the distance. As puffins their bellies bulging with food take flight from the ship's path, Dr. Terry Whitledge recalls the conditions that led to the massive plankton bloom seen here three years ago.
